column1: Bundaberg is a city in south-east Queensland
column3: about 385 kilometres (239 mi) north of the state capital
column4: Brisbane. It is 15 kilometres (9.3 mi) inland from the Coral Sea coast and situated on the Burnett River. It is a major centre within the broader Wide Bay–Burnett geographical region

column1: Bundaberg is the business centre for a major sugar cane growing area
column2: and is well known for its namesake export
column3: Bundaberg Rum. The city is an important tourism gateway for inland national parks and the southern end of the Great Barrier Reef and resort islands. It is the seat of the Bundaberg Regional Council.

column1: The name was coined by surveyor John Charlton Thompson and his assistant Alfred Dale Edwards. Bunda is derived from the name of one of the kinship groups of the local Taribelang people
column2: to which was added the Saxon suffix berg
column3: meaning "town". Colloquially the city is known as "Bundy".

column1: Bourbong Street is the main street of the city and there is some controversy in regards to its spelling and meaning; Bourbong was alternatively spelled Bourbon or Boorbong
column2: which was a local Aboriginal title given to a large waterhole in the area. The main street was historically also gazetted in the Bundaberg Mail as "Bourbon" street
column3: but by 1941 there is no reference to "Bourbon" street. Robert Strathdee's farming selection in the vicinity of the watering holes was recorded on early survey maps as 'Boorbung'.A pioneer pastoralist of the region
column5: wrote that "Bourbong" was derived from the local Aboriginal phrase "bier rabong"
column7: who took up land in the area in the early 1860s
column8: found that Aboriginal people resolutely avoided the "bier rabong" vicinity. He later found the skeletal remains there of around twenty Aboriginal people who were apparently massacred in a raid by the Native Police.

column1: The local Aboriginal group is the Taribelang Bunda people. They are the original inhabitants of the region which stretches from the Burrum River in the south to the Baffle Creek in the north.The kinship groups of the Taribelang people are called Balguin

The first non-indigenous man to visit the area was James Davis in the 1830s. He was an escaped convict from the Moreton Bay Penal settlement who lived with the Kabi people to the south of the region. He resided mostly around the Mary River and was referred to as Durrumboi. The Burnett River was surveyed by John Charles Burnett
column2: after whom it was named during his exploration mission of the Wide Bay and Burnett regions in 1847.British occupation of the land in the region began in 1848 when pastoral squatters Gregory Blaxland Jnr and William Forster established a sheep station. Blaxland was a son of the Blue Mountains explorer
column4: and Forster was later to become a Premier of New South Wales. They selected a very large area of land which encompassed most of the western part of the modern day Bundaberg Region along the Burnett River. They named this pastoral lease Tirroan. Blaxland and Forster had previously set up sheep stations near the Clarence River and had a notable history of conflict with Aboriginal people. This continued at Tirroan when two of their shepherds were killed by Aboriginal people in 1849. Forster and Blaxland led a punitive expedition causing multiple Aboriginal deaths. Further conflict occurred the following year when Blaxland was clubbed to death. Forster and a number of other squatters conducted another reprisal
column5: resulting in a large massacre of Aboriginal people in scrubland toward the coastal part of Tirroan. In the early 1850s
column6: Forster sold the property to Alfred Henry Brown who changed the name of the pastoral lease to Gin Gin. At the same time
column9: took up the Bingera leasehold in the rainforest scrubland downstream from Tirroan. Three towns in the Bundaberg region

column2: much of the land around the lower reaches of the Burnett River consisted of either the Woongarra Scrub
column3: a subtropical rainforest that stood where most of the Bundaberg canefields now grow
column5: a lightly timbered grassland that stretched along the coastal fringe. Neither of these areas were suitable for sheep farming but the British soon found that raising cattle was possible. In the early 1860s the first cattle stations in the area were established; Branyan on the south side of the Burnett River and Tantitha on the north side.Timber companies
column6: such as that owned by William Pettigrew
column7: started the logging of the Woongarra Scrub in 1867.

column2: Samuel Johnston erected a sawmill in Waterview
column3: on the north bank of the Burnett River. The Waterview sawmill became a prominent supplier of timber until its closure in 1903 after being damaged by flood.

column4: established the Woondooma property which consisted of a few houses and a wharf on the northern banks of the Burnett River where Bundaberg North now stands. An official survey of the area was undertaken in 1869 by John Charlton Thompson
column5: assisted by James Ellwood and Alfred Dale Edwards
column6: and the town of Bundaberg was gazetted across the river on the higher
column7: southern banks. The first Bundaberg land sale was held in Maryborough on 11 May 1870 where hotelier John Foley bought the original lots.

column1: Most of the early settlers exploited the timber and grew maize on their selections but as a result of the incentives of the Sugar and Coffee Regulations of 1864
column2: sugar became a major component in Bundaberg's development from the 1870s.  Experimental sugar cane cultivation in the district was first grown at John Charlton Thompson's Rubyanna property in 1870 and the first sugar mill was built by Richard Elliot Palmer at his Millbank plantation in 1872. Bundaberg rapidly became an important sugar production region after the construction of the Millaquin Sugar Refinery at East Bundaberg by Robert Cran and his sons in 1882. The Fairymead sugar processing plant owned by the Young Brothers (Arthur
column3: Horace and Ernest Young) opened in 1884 which further augmented Bundaberg's sugar producing capacity.

column1: The initial 35 years of the sugar industry in Bundaberg was reliant on South Sea Islander workers
column2: who were often blackbirded and kept in a status close to slavery. The first significant shipload of Kanaka labour
column4: to arrive on the Burnett River came in January 1872 aboard the Petrel. Allegations of kidnapping and wounding immediately arose concerning the recruitment of the Islanders on this vessel. Influential Bundaberg plantation owners were able to purchase recruiting ships in order to obtain labour directly from areas such as the Solomon Islands and the New Hebrides. The Young Brothers owned the Lochiel and the May vessels
column5: the Cran family and Frederic Buss were the major investors in the Helena while the Ariel was co-owned by a number of local planters. While some of the recruitment was voluntary
column6: violence and deception toward Islanders often took place. For example
column7: the crew of the Helena fought a battle with the locals of Ambrym while taking Islanders from there.These labourers had to work for three years and were only paid at the end of this time period. Instead of cash
column8: they usually received substandard goods and trinkets of minimal value as payment. Excessive mortality of the Islanders while serving their term of labour in the Bundaberg region was frequent. Overwork
column11: contaminated water supplies and a lack of medical care all contributed to the high death rate. Penalties for the plantation owners whose neglect resulted in these fatalities were rare and did not exceed a £10 fine. Importing South Sea Islander labour was made illegal in 1904 and enforced repatriation of these workers out of Bundaberg and other locations in Queensland occurred from 1906 to 1908.

column1: The 1911 Queensland sugar strike occurred after the phasing out of South Sea Islander labour
column2: with workers claiming that many plantation owners had substituted black indentured labourers (sometimes referred to as slaves) with white ones. Workers sought better accommodation
column4: including an eight-hour day and a minimum weekly wage of 30 shillings
column5: including food. The mobilisation of unionists from Bundaberg to Mossman was a major achievement
column6: with the 1911 strike lasting over seven weeks in Bundaberg where the town's economy was largely based on the sugar industry. The end result of the strike was a Commonwealth Royal Commission into the sugar industry in 1911–12
column7: which had been initially requested by Harry Hall
column8: a Bundaberg AWA organiser in 1908 with a petition signed by 1500 Bundaberg sugar workers. The Royal Commission
column9: with ALF Secretary Albert Hinchcliffe as secretary
column10: concluded the AWA demands had been justified. The union victory was a watershed in organised labour in Queensland and Australia.

column1: St Joseph's School opened on June 1876.With the passage of the Local Authorities Act 1902
column2: Barolin Division became the Shire of Barolin and the Borough of Bundaberg became the Town of Bundaberg on 31 March 1903. On 22 November 1913
column3: Bundaberg was proclaimed a City.In 1912 Bundaberg pioneering aviator Bert Hinkler built and successfully flew his own glider on Mon Repos beach. He also completed a noteworthy non-stop flight from London to Turin in 1920. The following year in 1921 Hinkler flew from Sydney to Bundaberg
column5: in a record breaking flight of 8 and a half hours
column6: in the process beating a telegram he had sent to his mother
column7: to warn her of his arrival.The Bundaberg War Memorial commemorating those who died in the Anglo-Boer War and World War I was unveiled by Major-General Charles Brand on 30 July 1921. The Bundaberg digger was imported from Italy and is constructed of Italian marble. The completed memorial
column10: was the third most costly to be erected in Queensland. It is a major regional memorial and one of the two most intact digger memorials that remain in their original settings of intersections.

column1: In the 1960s the township was completely flooded by the Burnett river. In 1967 Bundaberg celebrated its centenerary by producing a coin and opening The Bundaberg and District Historical Museum in the Bundaberg Botanical Gardens in Bundaberg North.

column2: Bundaberg suffered its worst floods in 60 years
column3: when floodwaters from the Burnett River inundated hundreds of homes.Two years later
column5: Bundaberg experienced its worst flooding in recorded history as a result of Cyclone Oswald. Floodwaters from the Burnett River peaked at 9.53 meters. Over 4000 properties and 600 businesses had been affected by floodwaters
column6: which moved in excess of 70 km/h. Two defence force Blackhawk helicopters were brought in from Townsville as part of the evacuation operation
column7: which ultimately used an additional 14 aircraft.

column2: Prince Charles visited Bundaberg Rum Distillery He stated
column3: “I'm thrilled that this Distillery's proving to be the one that produces some of the most famous and special of all rums around the world."

column1: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people made up 4.3% of the population.
81.2% of people were born in Australia. The next most common countries of birth were England 3.2%
88.9% of people spoke only English at home. Other languages spoken at home included Mandarin 0.5%
The most common responses for religion were No Religion 26.3%

Bundaberg has a humid subtropical climate (Cfa) with wet hot summers and mild winters. The climate is rated the most equable of any Australian town or city and ranked 5th on a worldwide comparison. The mean daily maximum temperature is highest in January at 30.3 °C (86.5 °F)
column2: and the mean daily minimum is lowest in July at 9.9 °C (49.8 °F). The coldest temperature recorded in Bundaberg is −0.7 °C (30.7 °F)
column3: and some inland areas of Bundaberg sometimes experience frosts. The mean annual rainfall is 1

column1: Subtropical Bundaberg is dependent to a large extent on the local sugar industry. Extensive sugar cane fields have been developed throughout the district. Value-adding operations
column2: such as the milling and refinement of sugar
column4: are located around the city. A local factory that manufactured sugar-cane harvesters was closed down after it was taken over by the US multinational corporation Case New Holland. Most of the raw sugar is exported. A bulk terminal for the export of sugar is located on the Burnett River east of Bundaberg.

column1: Another of the city's exports is Bundaberg Rum
column2: made from the sugar cane by-product molasses. Bundaberg is also home to beverage producer Bundaberg Brewed Drinks
column3: Craft Brewery Bargara Brewing Company and Craft Distillery Kalki Moon.

column1: Commercial fruit and vegetable production is also significant: avocado
column24: zucchini. Macadamia nuts are also grown.Because of its high rate of unemployment
column25: Bundaberg has been referred to as the "dole capital of Australia".

column1: Tourism is an important industry in Queensland
column2: and Bundaberg is known as the 'Southern Gateway to the Great Barrier Reef'. The city lies near the southern end of the reef in proximity to Lady Elliot and Lady Musgrave Islands. The nearby town of Bargara is an increasingly popular holiday and retirement destination.

column1: The Mon Repos turtle rookery is located on the coast just east of Bundaberg. The northern bank of the Burnett River between the Don Tallon and Burnett bridges is home to a colony of flying foxes.Nearby beaches are popular with both locals and tourists. Moore Park Beach
column3: has 20 kilometres (12 mi) of golden sandy beach. Beaches on the southern side of the Burnett River are (from north to south) the Oaks Beach
Eurimbula National Park and Kinkuna National Park
column4: located in the Bundaberg region are popular with campers and bush-lovers.Tours of the Bundaberg Rum distillery and attractions at Bundaberg Botanic Gardens
column5: such as the 2 ft narrow gauge Australian Sugar Cane Railway
column6: are also popular with tourists. The Mystery Craters
column7: 35 unexplained water-filled holes in the ground
column9: are also a tourist attraction.Opened in 2002 by the former member for Hinkler Paul Neville
column10: the Tom Quinn Community Centre gardens (a multiple "Bundy in Bloom" winner) is a site to be seen with local flora and fauna
column16: woodwork and indigenous nature section.Opened in December 2008
column17: the Hinkler Hall of Aviation is an historical aviation tourist attraction that celebrates pioneer solo aviator Bert Hinkler. In 1928
column18: Hinkler was the first person to fly solo from England to Australia. The museum includes an exhibition hall
column22: five aircraft and the historic Hinkler House.

column1: Other local attractions and events include the Whaling Wall
column9: reef tours of Lady Musgrave & Lady Elliiot islands

column1: Bundaberg has two cinemas. The Reading Cinemas
column4: and the Moncrieff Entertainment Centre (formerly known as the Moncrieff Theatre)
column6: central Bundaberg. The Moncrieff Entertainment Centre also holds live musical and theatrical performances year round.The Bundaberg Regional Art Gallery (BRAG) is a large multi-purpose visual arts facility located in central Bundaberg. The Bundaberg Regional Council operates a public library at 49 Woondooma Street.

column1: The NewsMail newspaper is published in Bundaberg from Monday to Saturday. It is available in print and online.
Several community newspapers are also available including the Guardian
Bundaberg is served by three commercial television stations (Seven Queensland
column2: WIN Television and Nine) and publicly owned services (ABC TV) and (SBS).

column1: Local news coverage of Bundaberg and the Wide Bay is provided on all three commercial networks with both Seven Queensland's Seven Local News and WIN Queensland's WIN News half-hour bulletins airing at 6pm each weeknight. Southern Cross Austereo also airs brief local news updates at various intervals throughout the day on Channel 9
The city has been the location for three film sets:
Most major Australian sporting codes are played in Bundaberg.
Bundaberg has two current clubs playing in the AFL Wide Bay competition.
Across The Waves Bundaberg Eagles (merger of North Bundaberg and Souths/ATW Magpies)
Bundaberg has two professional teams competing in the ConocoPhillips Central Queensland Cup. They are the Bundaberg Autobarn Bulls (men) and Bundaberg Bears (women) and both feature local players.

column3: is home to the Queensland State Rowing Championships every year in December.

column1: The Bundaberg Rugby Football League is a nine-club competition run under the Queensland Rugby League's Central Division. Bundaberg competes in the Central Division's 47th Battalion Shield and the Bundaberg Grizzlies formerly competed in the Queensland Cup statewide competition.
Bundaberg was home to the Bundaberg Spirit soccer club. They participated in the Queensland State League against other teams across Queensland.
The Bundaberg & District Tennis Senior Association operates eleven floodlit clay courts in Drinan Park
column2: Bundaberg West at the corner of George & Powers Streets. Competition tennis is played all year round. The Bundaberg & District Junior Tennis Association operates five artificial grass courts

column1: The Bundaberg branch of the Queensland Country Women's Association meets at the QCWA Hall at 15 Quay Street
column2: Bundaberg Central. The Hinkler branch of the Queensland Country Women's Association meets at the McDonalds Central Bundaberg on the corner of Woongarra & Targo Street

column1: There are many public and private primary schools in Bundaberg. Bundaberg South State School opened on 11 May 1891
column2: with an enrollment of 167 students and under the direction of William Benbow. The school celebrated its 125-year anniversary in 2016.Bundaberg has three public high schools
column3: Bundaberg North State High School which opened on 29 January 1974
column4: Bundaberg State High School which opened on 30 January 1912  (the second-oldest high school in Queensland that is still open) and Kepnock State High School which opened on 28 January 1964. There are also three main private secondary schools: Shalom Catholic College

column1: There is a campus of the Wide Bay Institute of Technical and further education on Walker St and a campus of the Central Queensland University
column2: located adjacent to the airport. There is a campus of the Booth College at the Salvation Army's Tom Quinn Community Centre.

column1: Bundaberg Airport has flights to Brisbane and Lady Elliot Island. The city is home to the Jabiru Aircraft Company
column2: which designs and manufactures a range of small civil utility aircraft.

column1: Bundaberg's bus operator is Duffy's City Buses. As of 2013
column2: they transport over 1000 passengers in town services
column3: and over 2000 passengers in school services every day. Routes extend to the beach suburbs of Burnett Heads
column5: and Innes Park. Stewart & Sons also operates bus services in the area.

column1: Bundaberg is serviced by several Queensland Rail passenger trains
column2: including the Tilt Train and is approximately four and a half hours north of Brisbane by rail. The closed North Bundaberg station formerly served the Mount Perry railway line and is now a museum.

column1: Bundaberg is situated at the end of the Isis Highway (State Route 3)
column2: approximately 50 kilometres (31 mi) east of its junction with the Bruce Highway. Many long-distance bus services also pass through the city.

column1: Bundaberg Port is located 20 kilometres (12 mi) northeast of the city
column2: at the mouth of the Burnett River. The port is a destination for ships from Australia and overseas. It is predominantly used for shipping raw sugar and other goods related to that industry such as Bundaberg Rum.

column1: Bundaberg is served by three hospitals. One public hospital
column2: Bundaberg Base Hospital on Bourbong St
column4: Friendly Society Private Hospital & Mater Hospital.

column1: The Friendly Society Hospital has undergone a redevelopment and forms part of the GP Super Clinic Program.Bundaberg is also home to the Royal Flying Doctor Service
column2: who regularly transport patients to Bundaberg from more rural and remote areas
column3: as well as transferring critically ill patients to Brisbane for specialist care.

column1: Bundaberg houses two military bases. Bundaberg Army Barracks and Training Ship (TS) Bundaberg. Bundaberg barracks contains mostly infantrymen and army cadets. TS Bundaberg houses mostly Cadet staff and Navy Cadets.
The city council responsible for the Bundaberg Region maintains Sister City arrangements with two cities.
